abstract.p: Letter from Anne Teare Freedman letter on May 9 article on advances in prenatal testing, which were not available when she was pregnant with severely handicapped baby

block.p: If doctors had been able to give me the information about my baby prenatally that they gave me when my son was 6 months old, in 1995, I would have seriously considered abortion (''Advances, and Angst, in a New Era of Ultrasound,'' May 9).

To put a little baby through the ''life'' that the doctors described seemed unthinkable. My son has the most severe form of spinal muscular atrophy, a common genetic cause of death in young children. Then, technology was not available to diagnose it prenatally.

If doctors had been able to give me the information about my baby prenatally that they gave me when my son was 6 months old, in 1995, I would have seriously considered abortion (''Advances, and Angst, in a New Era of Ultrasound,'' May 9).

To put a little baby through the ''life'' that the doctors described seemed unthinkable. My son has the most severe form of spinal muscular atrophy, a common genetic cause of death in young children. Then, technology was not available to diagnose it prenatally.
As things happened, Jack was already here, smiling constantly and living. His care is demanding and the emotional strain is very difficult at times, but I cannot imagine my life without him.
Jack is a constant inspiration to his family and community, he has shown us what is meaningful in life in so many ways.

I am concerned that when doctors share prenatal information, they are neglecting the information that many families with special-needs children would share: that you will love this ''imperfect'' child completely, hope for his life constantly and find the idea of ending his life unimaginable.
ANNE TEARE FREEDMAN West Chester, Pa.
